Synopsis:
Pawan Kumar Chaturvedi a.k.a Bajrangi (Salman Khan), comes across a little girl, who cannot speak and is lost. He befriends her, Calls her Munni (Harshaali Malhotra) and virtually adopts her, thinking she is a Hindu and a Brahmin. Later he finds out, through a series of incidents, that She is a Muslim and a Pakistani at that. He decides to restore her to her parents. He has no Passport, no visa and no contacts, only his faith and his love for Munni. He crosses over to Pakistan illegally.

In Pakistan he is befriended by a journalist, Chand Nawab (Nawazuddin Siddiqui), who believes his tale. This unlikely trio now faces danger and many adventures as Bajrangi is labelled an Indian Spy. What they do next is the story of Bajrangi Bhaijaan.

Comments:
It is an unusual theme - restoring a lost child to her parents across a hostile border and perhaps it is the pent up goodwill among the peoples of the two countries that made this film the superhit it became. The other reason was probably Harshaali Malhotra, with her dimpled cheeks and winning ways. She effortlessly wins your heart, not just that of Bajrangi Bhaijaan. Fortunately, we don't meet such little girls everyday, or a continuous cross-border traffic would emerge!

Salman Khan is his usual self. Part heroic, part naive and with an unalloyed golden heart. The role is written with him in mind and he hams his way through. Nawazuddin Siddiqui is outstanding as the Pakistani journalist. Kareena Kapoor has little to do except look pretty, which she manages to be in occasional scenes.

Yet, despite the crazy tale, the Director makes the film almost believable, thanks to a very taut screenplay. Remember, this film goes on for about 2Â½ hours. It repeatedly touches your heartstrings with some incidents that are commonplace but seeks to show that people are the same everywhere.

Music adds to the film, despite the accusations of copyright violation. Editing is excellent and so is camera work.

Its not a film for rational thought. Its really a fairy tale, but everyone of us is a little child inside and everyone loves a good fairy tale!
